title: Steel firm Celsa fined £1,800,000 after two workers died in explosion
text:
Peter O’Brien (L) and Mark Sim were killed (Picture: Media Wales)

A steel company will have to pay a £1.8 million penalty after two engineers were killed in a factory explosion.

Celsa was fined after admitting breaching health and safety regulations at the firm’s steelworks in Cardiff, which led to the deaths of Peter O’Brien, 51, and Mark Sim, 41.

A lack of safety procedures caused a pressurised oil tank to explode at 10.30am on November 18 2015, while it was being drained in the factory’s basement, Cardiff Crown Court heard today.

The tank exploded after an oil heater failed to switch off because of an electrical fault, which both victims were unaware of.

This led liquid to turn to vapour, creating a flammable atmosphere inside the tank that ignited.

Prosecutor Simon Morgan said: ‘The explosion caused extensive damage to the cellar area and to the bar mill above.

‘Oil expelled by the blast set alight and the cellar area was flooded as pumps and pipes were damaged. More importantly, it caused the two men to die.’

Peter O’Brien was killed in the explosion in Cardiff (Picture: Media Wales)

The force of the explosion lifted steel floor plates upwards at speeds of 40mph and hit the roof of the building some 46 feet above.

Other workers tried to help the victims but were forced back by fire and smoke.

Electrical engineer Darren Wood injured his hip and skull in the explosion while working on the floor above.

Mr Morgan said the workers should have received training to look out for faults with the system and assess the risks of operating the machinery.

The factory’s health and safety manager Richard Bowen revealed he had concerns for safety during an interview.

He said some employees had ‘little or no training’ on risk assessments, and Celsa had not put in place steps to make sure workers carried them out.

Mr Bowen added: ‘Prior to the accident there did not appear to be any corporate knowledge of process safety.’

Mark Sim also died on November 18, 2015 (Picture: Media Wales)

Celsa had failed to review working methods despite a smaller explosion occurring two years before the incident, the court heard.

It was also told the firm had breached health and safety legislation on five previous occasions between 2005 and 2009, with one occasion involving a death.

Richard Matthews, defending, said the company accepted it had failed to identify risk of explosion when the oil tank was drained, saying: ‘It was the cause of this tragedy and cause of these men’s deaths, and the cause of the suffering and incalculable pain that has resulted.’

He added: ‘We underline that nothing that occurred was as a result of any failure or error or mistake of any sort on the men’s part.’

Judge Neil Bidder criticised Celsa for not imposing a recognised set of instructions on how to safely drain the oil tank, describing its approach as ‘simply a recipe for disaster’.

Celsa was ordered to pay a fine of £1.8 million within six months.

Following the hearing a spokesman for Celsa said in a statement: “We are truly sorry for the shortcomings which contributed to the most tragic event in our history.’
